title: 113_s2384
content: The Act titled "Deter Cyber Theft Act of 2014" addresses economic or industrial espionage in cyberspace. The President must submit a report on foreign economic and industrial espionage in cyberspace annually, identifying countries engaged in espionage with respect to trade secrets owned by US persons. The President must submit an annual report on foreign economic and industrial espionage in cyberspace, identifying countries engaged in espionage with respect to trade secrets owned by US persons. This includes technologies or proprietary information developed by US persons targeted for economic or industrial espionage in cyberspace. The annual report must identify foreign countries engaged in economic and industrial espionage in cyberspace, detailing actions taken by the President to decrease such espionage and the progress made in reducing its prevalence. The President must identify foreign countries engaging in economic or industrial espionage in cyberspace with respect to trade secrets owned by US persons, based on their government's involvement or support of such activities. The President may impose sanctions on individuals or entities from foreign countries involved in economic or industrial espionage in cyberspace. Reports must be submitted in unclassified form but may contain a classified annex. Sanctions can include blocking transactions in property located in the United States. The President has the authority to impose sanctions on foreign individuals or entities engaged in economic or industrial espionage in cyberspace. Sanctions do not cover the importation of goods. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in Congress. The appropriate congressional committees in Congress for cyberspace issues include the Senate's Committees on Armed Services, Banking, Homeland Security, Finance, Foreign Relations, and Intelligence, as well as the House's Committees on Armed Services, Homeland Security, Financial Services, Foreign Affairs, Ways and Means, and Intelligence. Cyberspace refers to interconnected information technology networks, including the Internet and telecommunications. The term "economic or industrial espionage" involves stealing trade secrets or proprietary information without authorization, through various means such as copying, transmitting, or conveying the information. The term "knowingly" refers to a person having actual knowledge or should have known about unauthorized use of trade secrets or proprietary information. "Own" means holding rightful legal or equitable title to the information. Equitable title to, or license in, the trade secret or proprietary information. Person means an individual or entity. Proprietary information includes competitive bid preparations, negotiating strategies, executive emails, internal financial data, strategic business plans, technical designs, manufacturing processes, source code, data derived from research and development investments, and other commercially valuable information that has been kept confidential and is not generally known. Technology has its own meaning. In the context of proprietary information and trade secrets, technology is defined as per the Export Administration Act of 1979, and a trade secret is defined as per title 18, United States Code. A United States person is defined as a citizen, resident, or entity organized under U.S. laws.
